question_1.question: What is the purpose of a securable column in TimeXtender's data area security?

options.option_b: To contain values used in the filter for row level security

question_1.explanation: A securable column contains values that are used as filters to determine which data a user or role can access, enabling row level security.

question_2.question: How is a secured view used in the context of row level security?

options.option_a: To display all data in the database
options.option_c: To filter out data the user does not have access to

question_2.explanation: A secured view filters out all data that the user does not have access to, making it an essential component for implementing row level security.

question_3.question: What happens when a user not listed in the Securable Column Setup logs into PowerBI?

options.option_a: They can see all the data
options.option_b: They can see only their own data
options.option_c: They can see data based on default permissions
options.option_d: No information is available in the secured view

question_3.explanation: If a user not listed in the Securable Column Setup logs into PowerBI, they will not be able to see any information in the secured view.

question_4.question: What is the result of dragging the SalesRepSecurity securable column onto the Logon field in the Sales facts table?

options.option_a: It creates a new user account
options.option_b: It generates a report of sales data
options.option_c: It creates the DSA2.Sales_SV secured view
options.option_d: It deletes the Logon field from the table

question_4.explanation: Dragging the SalesRepSecurity securable column onto the Logon field in the Sales facts table creates the DSA2.Sales_SV secured view, which is used for row level security.
